criteria: Identification of Different Points of View
descriptions: Fails to identify any points of view present in the text.
Identifies at least one point of view with significant inaccuracies.
Identifies the points of view of the characters OR the audience/reader but not both, with minor inaccuracies.
Identifies the points of view of the characters AND the audience/reader but struggles to clearly explain the distinction.
Clearly identifies the points of view of the characters and the audience/reader, demonstrating understanding of their differences.
Masterfully identifies and articulates the distinct points of view of characters and audience/reader, providing insightful examples.
Unable to connect the points of view to any effect such as suspense or humor.
Attempts to connect the points of view to effects, but the analysis is vague or unsupported.
Connects differences in points of view to EITHER suspense OR humor, with limited explanation.
Connects differences in points of view to BOTH suspense AND humor, but the analysis lacks depth.
Analyzes how differences in points of view create suspense OR humor with clear, specific examples from the text.
Expertly analyzes how differences in points of view create suspense AND humor, providing nuanced, well-supported interpretations from the text.
Does not recognize or define dramatic irony.
Attempts to define dramatic irony, but the definition is inaccurate or incomplete.
Recognizes dramatic irony in the text but does not explain its effect.
Understands and identifies dramatic irony, partially explaining its contribution to suspense or humor.
Clearly explains how dramatic irony contributes to the creation of suspense or humor within the text, with supporting details.
Demonstrates a sophisticated understanding of dramatic irony, thoroughly explaining its effects on the audience/reader and its role in developing suspense or humor.
